In some ICUs the students are taught directly by faculty performing service responsibilities (ICU Attending) and in others, there are dedicated Student Teaching Attendings. Students also attend lectures, workshops and simulations to help deliver curriculum content.   ICU and CCU Student Teaching Attending   Goal:  To teach medical students to care for critically ill patients.   Role:  You will meet a group of students in an ICU setting three times a week for four weeks. You will assess each student’s ability to elicit a history, perform a physical examination, interpret laboratory and radiographic tests, present the information in a cohesive manner, synthesize all the information into a diagnosis, and provide general goals of care while in the ICU. This role includes modeling professional behavior, observing the student perform elements of the history and physical examination, reviewing the underlying pathophysiology with the student, and providing up to date treatment options. The role also includes giving feedback to students and submitting student evaluations at the midpoint and upon completion of clerkship.   Faculty Commitment:  This role requires 24 hours of direct student teaching over the four week block. There is an additional 24 hours of preparatory time and administrative time required for this role.   Interested Faculty should contact Dr. Norma Keller , the Clerkship Director.   ICU and CCU Teaching Attending   Goal:  To oversee the delivery of ICU level care to patients while simultaneously training fellows, residents and students.   Role:  As you normally round with the ICU team, you will teach the entire team how to care for the critically ill patient. This role includes allowing students to present cases during rounds and observing them while they examine patients. Faculty should provide feedback to students at least once near the midway point of the clerkship. Also, ICU Teaching Attendings evaluate students using the online evaluation system.   Faculty Commitment:  This role includes the education of three types of learners. On average, ICU teams round for 24 hours per week which translates into an average time commitment of 96 hours per four week block. Additionally there is an additional 24 hours of administrative and preparatory time required to perform this role.   This role is combined with service responsibility in one of the ICU’s at NYU’s core teaching facilities.   Simulation Instructor   Goal:  To facilitate a simulation scenario for a group of students.   Role:  You will facilitate simulation scenarios with a group of 5 students that demonstrates important aspects of critical care medicine (i.e. the recognition and treatment of severe sepsis) as well as leadership and team building exercises. You will teach airway management principles and demonstrate proper aoirway management techniques and intubation. You will observe each student perform these activities and provide feedback.   Faculty Commitment:  Each simulation requires three hours of teaching time plus four hours of preparatory time.   Interested Faculty should contact Dr. Norma Keller, the Clerkship Director.   Lecturer:  The goal is to deliver curriculum content to groups of students taking the clerkship.   Each lecture represents 1.5 hours of teaching time plus three hours of preparatory time.   Interested Faculty should contact Dr. Norma Keller , the Clerkship Director.   Workshop Leader   Goal:  Familiarize students with principles of acid-base, respiratory physiology and ventilation management.   Role:  Present material in an interactive format with hands on demonstration of different ventilator modes.   Commitment:  One and a half hours of teaching time plus three hours of preparatory time.   Interested Faculty should contact Dr. Norma Keller , the Clerkship Director. Division of Pediatric Critical Care |                                 Skip to main content                      Patient Care       Faculty & Staff Directory       Events       Careers       Donate                                                                                                                                                                             Division of Pediatric Critical Care                    DEPARTMENT OF PEDIATRICS                                                                                   Home   Patient Care   Medical Education   Research & Quality   Our Team                                  Home            Print  Email               - A + A                                                                                                                                           The Division of Pediatric Critical Care                                                                  The division of Pediatric Critical Care Medicine consists of two Pediatric Intensive Care Units (PICU) within the NYU Langone Medical Center (NYULMC). The Division is also involved in a busy inter-hospital transport service.   PICU at Tisch Hospital   PICU at Bellevue Hospital   Pediatric Transport Service   The Division provides active clinical services for medical and surgical critically ill patients with 1,000 admissions per year.  The two intensive care units are referral centers for severe pediatric seizure disorders, craniofacial dysmorphologies, acute organ dysfunction and coordination of technological support such as mechanical ventilation, renal replacement and cardiac output augmentation.   For a list of pediatric subspecialties offered at NYU Langone Medical Center call toll-free 855.NYU.KIDS. (855.698.5437)                                                             Our Team                    The Pediatric Critical Care faculty consists of five physicians with academic appointments at NYU School of Medicine; they are board certified/eligible in Pediatrics and in Pediatric Critical Care Medicine.       More               Medical Education                    During their rotations the pediatric residents acquire the medical knowledge, professionalism and medical ethics required for patient care in the PICU.       More               Research & Quality                    All faculty members engage in research or scholarly activity. This includes clinical prospective and retrospective studies, basic research and quality improvement projects.
